history.content:
They are exactly the same because the actual cs 188 class uses Edx for all of the course materials and project submission.

To the credit question:

To my knowledge -- no there's currently no plans or process for getting credit from edX courses. I'd love to be proven wrong though...
They are exactly the same because the actual cs 188 class uses Edx for all of the course materials and project submission.

children.subject: For one thing, there are exams... Seems like too important of a part of the class to allow the online version to count for a degree requirement.
maybe on the transcript, it should be notated p/np then, but still count as part of the degree. because it seems kind of redundant to take it on edx and then redo it in real life

I don't think you can pass the class without taking the exams :P

And yes, it is redundant, which is why you are not expected to be taking the edX version.

@op, what's most important is learning the material. So if you feel that material is important for your CS goals but can't manage to get 188 proper in your schedule, then by all means take the edX version. Nothing is keeping you from still listing it on your resume as a course you've taken, as long as you make it clear that it was an edX (read : self-learning) course.

No employers will preclude you from a job for learning AI informally if you can still demonstrate mastery of the material. In fact, I'm sure there are some who would think that that speaks more highly of you. That being said, you'll want to be sure that you are actually quizzing yourself, taking the assessments and completing the projects. I'm actually planning on doing the course myself over this summer, since I will not have the time to fit it into my schedule before I graduate due to other courses taking precedence.

I should add that if you are taking the course as a prereq in hopes of following up with 189, then I would say all of the above still applies. Do the edX, sign up for 189, and if you're questioned, speak with the professor and demonstrate mastery to him/her. It doesn't hurt to try, and like I said, in the end all that really matters is mastery of the material, both from the perspective of an employer, a professor, and hopefully yourself :)

Oh, right, no one answered that question about 189:

188 is usually not perceived to be strongly related to 189, and you could probably do fine without the class; 126, for example, is more relevant, as would be brushing up on your linear algebra.

1) how is the extra 3 weeks in real life that is not on edX accounted for?

2) if we have successfully completed the course on edX, can we petition to have that count towards degree requirements?

history.content: How does the cs188 course on edX compare to the cs188 course taken as a class? I notice that the course on edX is 12 weeks long, vs in real life we have 15 weeks of instruction, so apparently some material is cut out. But besides those 3 weeks, is there any other difference in terms of rigor of the course? Would cs188 on edX prepare me adequately for cs189? Can cs188 on edX be taken for credit to count as 1 technical upper div?
history.subject: cs 188 on edX
